title: Another Largely Forgotten Piece of American History, Brought Back to Life
content: I did not know anything about these murders against the Osage until I read this book, so this was a definite eye- opener for me. I had heard of the Osage tribe, yes, but I did not know they fell into tremendous oil wealth and, subsequently, saw their members slowly dying off, either through gunfire or poisoning, as greedy individuals tried to get their hands on some easy cash. The book details several of the known killings and the cold, callous, calculated murders are chilling and puzzling. Chilling, because of the gruesomeness of the murders; puzzling, because of the nonchalant behavior of those who plotted the killings. Even when confronted with the murders, most of the guilty individuals seem to have no remorse at all. They don’t even perceive what they did as immoral in any way.

title: Couldn't Put I Down
content: Killers of the Flower Moon is the true story of the numerous murders of members of the Osage Native American tribe during the early 1920s. It was referred to as the Reign of Terror.  The Osage community was incredibly wealthy because the supposedly worthless land in Oklahoma to which they had been confined since 1870 was found to contain some of the largest oil reserves in the United States. People flocked there to strip them of their wealth by any means possible including murder. The situation was exacerbated by the government policy that claimed the Osage were not competent enough to manage their money and thus White guardians were assigned to each Osage native for that purpose.  This of course resulted in the guardians stealing from and murdering their clients.

title: Verified Purchase
content: David Grann's "Killers of the Flower Moon" is an eye-opening look into an episode of American history of which I had never heard. In the early 20th Century, one of the many and ever-changing treaties between the US Government and Native Americans had assigned a major portion of Oklahoma to the Osage Indian tribe.  Surprisingly, it turned out to be extremely oil rich, and members of the tribe became millionaires.  They lived in mansions and had servants. Still, they suffered many indignities, such as having a "guardian" (usually a Caucasian) assigned to handle their business affairs, as native Americans were not deemed competent to handle their own money. One thing that surprised me was that there were no laws prohibiting interracial marriages among Caucasians and native Americans.  The reason I didn't expect such unions would be legal was knowing that interracial marriages among whites and blacks were not allowed until a Supreme Court case in the 1967.

title: A must read for every American citizen who wants to know the truth about our history!
content: In the 1920s, a series of mysterious deaths began to occur among the Osage.  While some deaths resembled natural causes, they were unexplained and could have been the result of poisoning. Some were obviously murders, by gunshot wounds or stabbing. Multiple family members of Mollie Burkhart were among the victims. In those days, forensics as we know it today did not exist.  Autopsies were crude, and crime scenes were not preserved. When Mollie's sister was shot, the men who performed the autopsy could not find the bullet in her head, even though there was no exit wound. Law enforcement was extremely limited.  Citizens had to turn to private investigators for answers.  Material witnesses seemed to disappear or clam up.  A man went to Washington DC to seek help from federal authorities, but was ambushed and killed upon his arrival in the capitol city.

title: IF I COULD GIVE IT MORE THAN 5 STARS, I WOULD.
content: "Killers of the Flower Moon" tells the  shocking story of what was done to the Osage tribe in Oklahoma in the 1920's. At the time, the Osage was the wealthiest tribe in the U.S. thanks to rich oil deposits found on their reservation.  But, within a very few years, there were an untold number of killings and suspicious deaths on the reservation, and most of the wealth and mineral rights had been stripped from the Osage.  Eventually (some of) the murders were solved and prosecuted thanks to a tenacious Federal Agent of the newly created F.B.I.  But the pilfering had already been done thanks to  legislators, judges, lawyers, law enforcement, bankers, doctors, and people of the cloth. In other words, the most upstanding and well-respected citizens conspired against the Osage.  This didn't happen in the 1700's or the 1800's. It happened in the Twentieth Century! The case was splashed across the headlines at the time. Yet, I never read even one sentence about it in the history books.  "Killers of the Flower Moon"  should be required reading for all high school students in this country.  We need to stop sweeping shameful chapters under the rug.  Aren't we supposed to learn from our mistakes?  We must open our eyes and recognize injustice when we see it, not just see what we want to see. "Those who ignore history are bound to repeat it."

The little boy had a stick and he was pretending to shoot at something on the shore.  Without thinking, I asked, "Are you shooting Indians?"...not knowing that the little boy was himself half Indian. I thought I knew better. Yet in the recesses of my mind, I was still playing "Cowboys and Indians".  (SMH)

However, lawbreaking citizens managed to steal much of the money from the tribe members. When some tribe members ended up dead, the federal government got involved.
